text: She is hard at work, to music o.s.
Among the members of the sad burlesque audience, he is in strong contrast: a sour and aggressive expression. Music  o.s. We MOVE IN fast to a HEAD CLOSE-UP.
Labeled H-A-T-E in tattoo across four knuckles, it grips flexes.
Before we see the lettering he slides it into his pocket.
His head slants; a cold smile; one eyelid flutters.
We hear the snapping open of a switch-blade knife and the point of the knife cuts through his clothes.
He seems to "listen" for something.
No, there are too many of them; you  can't kill a world.
A hand descends firmly onto his shoulder. He glances up b him as we
He bends down and speaks quietly next PREACHER'S ear.
You driving an Essex tourin'-car  with a Moundsville license?
Harry Powell, for the theft of that  touring car you will spend thirty  days in the Moundsville Penitentiary.
(correcting Clerk) Preacher Harry Powell.
A car thief! Picked up where you  were! A man of God? (to Clerk) Harry Powell.
A grim stone turretted faзade; an American flag idles at center.
They sit in the grass, a sentimental picture. JOHN is nin PEARL is five. They are working together on PEARL'S doll; PEARL is dressing her, while JOHN gets on a difficult sho
Stand still, Miss Jenny!
(across her) There! What's so hard about that!
He proudly exhibits the shod foot. They hear the sound of an auto engine o.s. They look o.s. and get up, PEARL dangling the doll.
A Model-T Ford approaches at maximal speed on uneven dirt road.
(to John, happily) Daddy!

The car careens towards us; then swings into the sideyard we PAN, and stops. They run towards their father fast; then JOHN looks puzzl and they stop short. BEN HARPER half-falls out of the far door, his shoulder b stained, his eyes wild. A hefty, simple man of thirty. He looks at them, dazed, across the car.
Where's your Mom?
Out shopping -- you're bleeding, Dad --
Listen to me John.
On this he comes around clear of the car with a revolver one hand and a bloody roll of banknotes in the other.
He screams. BEN slaps him with the back of the money hand leaving blood on JOHN'S cheek.

PEARL, and the house, are in BACKGROUND. PEARL just clutc her doll. During BEN'S next lines, JOHN touches his cheek and looks at the blood on his fingers and at the bloody m of which we FLASH-CUT an INSERT.

(rushing) Listen! This money here! We got to  hide it before they get me! There's  close to ten thousand dollars. (his eyes dart wildly) Under a rock in the smokehouse? Ah  no. Under the bricks in the grape  arbor? No, they'd dig for it.
(sudden triumph) Why sure! That's the place!
He moves forward and OUT and in his place we see two poli cars, small in distance, coming fast. We hear sirens.
...and OVER two STATE TROOPERS. They move at high speed,  with sirens. BEN and his CHILDREN, tiny in the distance,  dilate.
(driving) That's him.
(over his shoulder,  as if to us) He prob'ly still has that gun.
...police cars approaching in BACKGROUND. PEARL hugs her  doll. JOHN is dazed. BEN stands, pistol in hand.
Here they come.
Dad, you're bleeding...
He grabs JOHN'S shoulder and stoops as we TIGHTEN IN.

Listen to me son. You got to swear.  Swear means promise. First swear  you'll take care of little Pearl.  Guard her with your life, boy. Then  swear you won't never tell where  that money's hid. Not even your Mom.
Yes, Dad.
You understand?
Not even her?
In b.g. the TROOPERS get out of their cars and fan out  cautiously to surround BEN: guns in hand.
You got common sense. She ain't.  When you grow up that money'll be  yours. Now swear. "I will guard Pearl  with my life..."
(fumbling) I will guard Pearl with my life...
..."and I won't never tell about the  money."
And I won't never tell about the  money.
You, Pearl. You swear too.
(giggling) Who's them Blue Men yonder?
(under breath) Blue men.
Ben Harper!
I'm goin' now children. Goodbye.
BEN backs away from his CHILDREN, raising his hands, gun one hand. We PULL BACK a little, enlarging the GROUP SHOT and the role of the TROOPERS in it.
Drop that gun, Harper. We don't want  them kids hurt.
TWO TROOPERS approach BEN from behind.
Just mind what you swore, son. Mind,  boy!
He runs forward and clasps his stomach, with his mouth op
One TROOPER smacks the back of BEN'S head with a pistol  barrel.
(shouting; a sickly  smile) Don't!
Another TROOPER, with a pistol barrel, knocks the pistol  from BEN'S lifted hand.
(shouting) Don't!
BEN sinks to his knees as both men, and two others from t front, close in on him.
Dad!
He takes in the GROUP with his mouth open. o.s. we hear t slamming of car doors, and car starting away.
They drive away fast in road dust.
Carrying a shopping bag, their mother, WILLA, runs up fro BACKGROUND between the CHILDREN, looking always to cars o
She has a rich body.
PEARL comes to her and she picks up PEARL and the doll; J laden with his oath, walks quickly into the house. WILLA  does a bewildered take, then looks again towards the cars o.s.
Ben Harper, it is the sentence of  this Court that for the murder of Ed  Smiley and Corey South, you be hanged  by the neck until you are dead, and  may God have mercy on your soul.

text: He lies on his back, chuckling and murmuring indistinctly his sleep.
I got you all buffaloed! You ain't  never gonna git it outen me; not  none o' you!
(o.s., very low) Where, Ben? Where? Where?
(distinctly) And a little child shall lead them.
BEN lies in profile. From the bunk above, the face of PRE stretches down into the SHOT, upside down, snake-like.
(softly) Come on, boy: tell me.
BEN wakes, sees PREACHER, and hits him so hard in the fac that he falls from bunk to floor. PREACHER collects himse into a squat, nursing his face. BEN sits up in bed.
(with wholesome dignity) Ben, I'm a Man of God.
Tryin' to make me talk about it in  my sleep!
No, Ben.
What'd I say? (he grabs Preacher's  throat and shakes  him) What? What? What? What?
(choking) You was quotin' Scripture. You said --  you said, "And a little child shall  lead them."
Hm!
He lies back, amused. PREACHER sits on the bedside; manne of a parson visiting the sick.
(gravely) You killed two men, Ben Harper.

That's right, Preacher. I robbed  that bank because I got tired of  seein' children roamin' the woodlands  without food, children roamin' the  highways in this year of Depression;  children sleepin' in old abandoned  car bodies on junk-heaps; and I  promised myself I'd never see the  day when my youngins'd want.
With that ten thousand dollars I  could build a Tabernacle that'd make  the Wheeling Island Tabernacle look  like a chicken-house!
Would you have free candy for the  kids, Preacher?
He picks up and wads a sock.
Think of it, Ben! With that cursed,  bloodied gold!
How come you got that stickknife hid  in your bed-blankets, Preacher?
I come not with Peace but with a  Sword.
You, Preacher?
PREACHER gets and pockets the knife.
That Sword has served me through  many an evil time, Ben Harper.
What religion do you profess,  Preacher?
The religion the Almighty and me  worked out betwixt us.
(contemptuously) I'll bet.
Salvation is a last-minute business,  boy.
(sock near mouth) Keep talkin', Preacher.
If you was to let that money serve  the Lord's purposes, He might feel  kindly turned towards you.
Keep talkin', Preacher.
He wads the sock into his mouth and lies back, sardonic.
(his voice fading  into Dissolve) You reckon the Lord wouldn't change  his mind about you if...
They rest on sill of cell window, the lettered fingers  legible. The right hand is lettered L-O-V-E. The hands op disclosing his open knife. They close over it.
His eyes lift from his hands, heavenward. Moonlight on hi face. He prays, quietly.
Lord You sure knowed what You was  doin' when You brung me to this very  cell at this very time. A man with  ten thousand dollars hid somewheres,  and a widder in the makin'.
Same SHOT as before, but now, prison lights are on; and a man, a prison GUARD, waits close inside door. BART the HA joins him with a silent salute. BART wears a hard derby.
They walk in silence into MEDIUM, MOVING SHOT, the GUARD  talkative, BART reluctant to talk. The Penitentiary recedes in b.g.
Any trouble?
No.
He was a cool one, that Harper. Never  broke.
He carried on some; kicked.
On porch, by door, is a doll's perambulator. BART and GUA walk into the SHOT. GUARD stops, BART starts up his front steps.
He never told about the money.
(walking up steps) No.
What do you figure he done with it?
(turning, at door) He took the secret with him when I  dropped him.
The GUARD leaves the SHOT; BART goes in.
He hangs up his coat and hat. Across this his wife speaks o.s.; a lighted door is ajar at rear of hall. A clatter o dishes and pans o.s.
(o.s.) That you, Bart? Supper's waitin'.
BART just nods, and, tiptoeing, walks into a door next th kitchen and snaps on a light and turns on water o.s. His  wife comes out of the kitchen and goes in.

He is washing his hands in thick lather. Passing, she pec his cheek and, as we PAN, looks into the next room. He lo past her, and we see two small CHILDREN asleep in a big b bed. BART registers, turns again to the basin, and we PAN them back into the original TWO-SHOT.
(low) Mother: sometimes I think it might  be better if I was to quit my job as  guard.
His WIFE'S eyes go sharp and quiet.
(low) You're always this way when there's  a hangin'. You never have to be there.
BART rinses his hands. A sigh; he takes up the towel.
Sometimes I wish I was back at the  mine.
And leave me a widow after another  blast like the one in '24? Not on  your life, old mister!
He looks at her a moment. She goes out. He looks o.s. tow his CHILDREN. He goes into their room on tiptoe.
He approaches his children, across whose bed WE SHOOT wit yet seeing them. He comes into MEDIUM CLOSE-UP. As he lea and we TILT DOWN, he extends his large hands.
Two rose-and-gold little GIRLS lie in sleep; BART'S hands enter the SHOT and gently rearrange the covers so that th mouths and throats are free. We watch, for a moment more, the two sleeping faces.
(o.s. chanting) Hing, hang, hung. See what the Hangman  done!

We are in Peacock Alley. The tree-shaded dirt street of a small, one-street river town; a picturesque, mid-19th-cen remnant of the old river civilization, which general prog has left behind. Chiefly we see, in this order: A schoolh (on far side of street); Miz Cunningham's second-hand sho a Grange House sporting a poster for a Western movie; Spo Ice Cream Parlor. At the end of this street, down the riv bank, is a brick wharf and UNCLE BIRDIE'S wharf-boat. In  b.g. and in passing, suggestions of sleepy small-town lif From the HEAD CLOSE-UP of BART the Hangman o.s. chanting,
Chanting VOICES o.s. complete "see what the Hangman done!
They stroll barefoot down the empty dirt sidewalk. They l towards the voices, PEARL friendly, JOHN hostile.

text: Several, within the door of the Schoolhouse, stick their  heads around the edge. They chant at the HARPER CHILDREN. Another, next the door, is drawing something on the wall.
(chanting) Hung, hang, hing! See the Robber  swing!
OVER these lines we CUT briefly to --
...chanting, drawing. The ARTIST completes in chalk, a la simple sketch of a man hanging from gallows. As the verse ends we CUT TO:

head_text.subj: THE CHILDREN, OVER JOHN AND PEARL

text: They look towards OUR CHILDREN; JOHN pays them no attenti The drawing is revealed. JOHN takes PEARL'S hand. The oth CHILDREN giggle.
(chanting) Hing, hang, hung! Now my song is  done!
Between lines one and two JOHN turns away from them into

We SHOOT them through the window of MIZ CUNNINGHAM'S seco hand store. The back of a watch is silhouetted large in  FOREGROUND; JOHN'S eyes instantly fix on it; in b.g. the  SCHOOL-CHILDREN finish their song and vanish, giggling, i the schoolhouse. We hear the ticking of the watch.
A watch with a moving sweep-hand, ticking.
Are you goin' to buy it, John?
No answer. JOHN'S eyes are fixed on the watch. OVER a sho doorbell we hear:
(o.s.) Uh-Hawwww! (They glance toward  her.)
Fantastically dirty and fantastically dressed, she hustle to them and we PAN her into a THREE-SHOT. She talks like Tidewater Cockatoo.
(continuing) So your Mommy's keepin' you out of  school! Poor little lambs!
PEARL watches her; JOHN, the watch.
And how is your poor, poor mother?
She's at Spoon's Ice Cream Parlor.
(she snuffles) The Lord tends you both these days!
JOHN doesn't take his eyes off the watch.
His eyes are fixed on the watch o.s.
(o.s.) Didn't they never find out what your  father done with all that money he  stole?
Eyes as before till "money," then he looks up towards her
When they caught him, there wasn't  so much as a penny of it to be seen!  Now what do you make of that! Eh,  boy?
She grins horribly.
Pearl and me, we have to go.
He walks off fast as we DOLLY BEHIND THEM; he leads PEARL who hugs her doll.
(chanting) Hing, hang, hung.
You better not sing that song.
Why?
'Cause you're too little.
A few paces in silence; now they come to the big window o Spoon's Ice Cream Parlor.
Can we get some candy?
WILLA'S face is seen within; serving a customer, she sees them and waves them away.
No.
He keeps her strolling. WALT SPOON, comes out, proffering two lollypops.
Howdy, youngins.
PEARL drags at JOHN'S hand but JOHN, pretending not to se or hear, drags her out of the SHOT, shaking his head. We  DOLLY IN on WALT, who looks after them, surprised and tou then goes inside.

We PAN WALT across a little of his Parlor; he plants the  lollypops back in a jar on the counter and leaves the SHO as we TIGHTEN IN on WILLA and ICEY. WILLA slides used dis into wash-water; ICEY jaws down her back, from first mome of shot.

Willa Harper there is certain plain  facts of life that adds up just like  two plus two makes four and one of  them is this: No woman is good enough  to raise growin' youngsters alone!  The Lord meant that job for two!
Icey, I don't want a husband.
(fiercely) Fiddlesticks!
The weekly movie audience is letting out, next door to  SPOON'S. Some start cars or wagons, others stroll to SPOO
We start with a CLOSE SHOT as ICEY'S hands slap together gooey banana split; TILT UP to TWO-SHOT, favoring ICEY; f on WILLA, on "it's a man you need," etc. Murmur of CUSTOMERS o.s.
(calling o.s.) One solid brown sody, one Lovers'  Delight.
'Tain't a matter of wantin' or not  wantin'! You're no spring chicken,  you're a grown woman with two little  youngins; it's a man you need in the  house, Willa Harper!
A short, lighted, toy-like train departs the town along t river-bank, whistling. The whistle TIES OVER the previous DISSOLVE. STARLIT SKY.
A square, HEAD-ON SHOT, river water below and vibrant  starlight above; featuring a gas-lamp by the road; a tree and pretty tree-shadows which work across a window.
PEARL lies in their bed, her doll snug on her shoulder. J sits on the edge of the bed, in his underwear.
Tell me a story, John.

Once upon a time there was a rich  king... (he sees the shadows  on the wall and gets  up and looks at them) ...and he had him a son and a daughter  and they all lived in a castle over  in Africa. Well, one day this King  got taken away by bad men and before  he got took off he told his son to  kill anyone that tried to steal their  gold, and before long these bad men  come back and --
The Blue Men?
He moves, and as his shadow moves away we see the shadow PREACHER, motionless. PEARL sits up and points at it. JOH notices her and sees it. We PAN JOHN to the window. He lo out.
He stands motionless.
He turns and we PAN him to bed.
(casually) Just a man. (he climbs into bed  and pulls up the  covers) Goodnight Pearl, sleep tight; and  don't let the bedbugs bite.
(to doll) 'Night Miss Jenny; don't let the  bedbugs bite.
As they settle down we hear PREACHER'S singing, sweet and quiet o.s.: "Leaning on the Everlasting Arms."
She steams around a bend towards a toy-like small town.  PREACHER'S song, o.s., ties over. People are waving from  shore and boat.
We PAN her into frame UNCLE BIRDIE STEPTOE'S toy-like lit wharf-boat. As she passes broadside we CUT TO:
...as boat passes. BIRDIE'S head sticks through a porthol He is a wiry old river character. The boat whistles. As B speaks we PAN JOHN, and foundered skiff, into TWO-SHOT wi BIRDIE.
She don't put in at Cresap's Landing  no more, but she still blows as she  passes. Come on in and have a cup of  coffee.
(starting towards him) Ain't nobody stole Dad's skiff.
Ain't nobody goin' to neither, long  as Uncle Birdie's around.
He vanishes from the porthole. We PAN JOHN from skiff to  wharf and Birdie's door.
(calling o.s.) First day my jints is limber enough  I'll haul her up and give her a good  caulkin'.
JOHN enters and sits on a box. BIRDIE, in a ramshackle ro chair, pours coffee. BESS'S photograph on chest near BIRD
Ain't seen you in a coon's age,  Johnny.
I been mindin' Pearl.
Pshaw now! Ain't it a caution what  women'll load onto a feller's back  when he ain't lookin'?
He gives JOHN a cup of coffee.
'Scuse me, Cap, while I sweeten up  my coffee.
He fetches a liquor bottle from beneath the rocking chair about to pour he does a take at BESS'S PHOTOGRAPH.
It stands in a cabinet frame: A fine-looking young woman archaic dress, with sharp, accusing black eyes.
(o.s.) Dead and gone these twenty-five years  and never takes her eyes off me.
CUT OVER his line to --
He turns the picture away and splashes liquor into his co
(pouring) Man o' my years needs a little snort  to get his boiler heated of a morning.
They drink. BIRDIE, satisfied, sighs and rocks.
This mornin' I was talkin' to this  stranger up at the boarding-house.  He knowed your Dad!
JOHN looks cautious.
Where did he know Dad?
BIRDIE'S face falls; he takes another drink.
Well, boy, I'll not hide the truth;  it was up at Moundsville Penitentiary.
JOHN puts his cup down and gets up.
I got to go now, Uncle Birdie.
He heads for the door.
Why shucks boy, you just got here.
He follows JOHN to the door. JOHN runs up the bank, not  looking back.
(running) I told Mom I'd be back to Spoon's  for Pearl.
He runs up the street close to Spoon's and stops dead.
He is horrified by what he sees.

GROUP SHOT through door-glass, from JOHN'S VIEW POINT  PREACHER, WILLA and PEARL surround a little table. WALT s by, puffing his pipe. ICEY in BACKGROUND, stirs fudge at little soda-fountain stove. WILLA looks both moved and  pleased. PEARL, shyly flirting with PREACHER, all but hid in WILLA'S skirts. PREACHER dandles PEARL'S doll on his k as he talks. All the grownups are avid for his words, whi we don't hear through the glass.
We SHOOT THROUGH the DOOR; he quietly enters.
They look casually to JOHN, and continue talking.
(stirring; with a  meaningful glance at  Willa) God works in a mysterious way, His  wonders to perform.
OVER this JOHN ENTERS the SHOT and stands at the fringe o the GROUP, staring at PREACHER'S hands and at the doll.
I was with Brother Harper almost to  the end;...
(continuing) ...and now that I'm no longer employed  by the Penitentiary it is my joy to  bring this small comfort to his loved  ones.
On "Penitentiary" he glances quickly at PREACHER'S face;  then back to his hands.
(sniffing) It's a mighty good man would come  out of his way to bring a word of  cheer to a grieving widow!
So you ain't with the State no more?
No, Brother; I resigned only  yesterday. The heart-renderin'  spectacle of them poor men was too  much for me.
He becomes aware of JOHN'S staring.
Ah, little lad, you're staring at my  fingers.
He hands the doll to PEARL. JOHN'S eyes follow the doll.  PREACHER holds up both hands to JOHN. JOHN looks back at hands.
Shall I tell you the little story of  Right-Hand-Left-Hand -- the tale of  Good and Evil?
JOHN stands still. PEARL, with her doll, crosses to PREAC and twines about his knee.
He looks on, in dumb alarm.

H-A-T-E! (he thrusts up his  left hand) It was with this left hand that old  brother Cain struck the blow that  laid his brother low! L-O-V-E! (he thrusts up his  right hand) See these here fingers, dear friends!  These fingers has veins that lead  straight to the soul of man! The  right hand, friends! The hand of  Love!
They are impressed in their different ways.

(o.s.) Now watch and I'll show you the Story  of Life. The fingers of these hands,  dear hearts! -- They're always a- tuggin' and a-warrin' one hand agin'  t'other. (he locks his fingers  and writhes them,  crackling the joints) Look at 'em, dear hearts!
He looks on with unseeing eyes.
(o.s.) Old Left Hand Hate's a-fightin' and  it looks like Old Right Hand Love's  a goner!
(o.s.) But wait now! Hot dog! Love's a- winnin! Yessirree!
It's Love that won! Old Left Hand  Hate's gone down for the count! (he crashes both hands  onto the table)
Slight applause from the ADULTS. PREACHER takes PEARL, wi her doll, onto his lap.
I never heard it better told. I wish  every soul in this community could  git the benefit. You jest got to  stay for our church pick-nick Sunday!
PEARL offers PREACHER the DOLL to kiss. PREACHER complies
(finessing it) I must wend my way down River on the  Lord's work.
You ain't leavin' in no hurry if we  can help it!
John: take that look offen your face  and act nice.
He don't mean no impudence; do you,  boy? (no answer) Do you, boy? Ah, many's the time  poor Brother Ben told me about these  youngins.
What did he tell you?
He does a little take. His eyes twinkle palely.
Why, he told me what fine little  lambs you and your sister both was.
Is that all?
Something new enters his eyes; a game has begun between t
Why, no, boy; he told me lots and  lots of things. Nice things, boy.
A tight silence. ICEY pours fudge into a buttered pan.
My, that fudge smells yummy!
(with horrid archness) It's for the pick-nick. And you won't  get a smidgen of my fudge unless you  stay for the pick-nick!
Over her line, o.s., hymn-singing begins and now, OVER he "the case rests" smile we bring up the singing and

A pleasant, grassy river-bank. Few men in proportion to w and children. We CENTER PREACHER. They are singing "Brigh the Corner;" PREACHER sings conspicuously well. The women watch him and admire him. He gives WILLA the eye as we PA to CENTER WILLA, who looks wooed and self-conscious. ICEY enters the SHOT and whispers and beckons WILLA and, as th singing continues, they leave the group and start towards shade tree in MEDIUM GROUND, which we PAN TO CENTER.
They walk; singers in BACKGROUND.
Don't he have the grandest singin'  voice?
WILLA nods. ICEY, looking ahead, is displeased.
They sit on the bench, their backs to us, partly conceale by the tree trunk.
(sharp) John! Pearl!
They look around. ICEY and WILLA enter the SHOT, their ba to us.
Run along and play, you two.
Where?
Down by the river. My goodness!
Docile, they leave the shot as WILLA and ICEY approach th bench.
They sit on the bench, their back to us. The CHILDREN rec towards the river in BACKGROUND. WILLA meekly keeps her h down. Singing continues o.s.
That feller's just achin' to settle  down with some nice woman and make a  home for himself.
It's awful soon after Ben's passing.
If ever I saw a Sign from Heaven!
John don't like him much.
Pearl dotes on him.
The boy worries me. It's silly, but  it's like there was something still  between him and his Dad.
What he needs is a dose o' salts!
There's something else.
What?
The money, Icey.
I declare, you'll let that money  haunt you to your grave, Willa Harper!
I would love to be satisfied Harry  Powell don't think I've got that  money somewhere.
You'll come right out and ask that  Man of God! (turning and yelling) Mr. Paow-well! (to Willa) Clear that evil mud out of your soul!
PREACHER starts towards her. ICEY pivots and we PAN OVER to CHILDREN by river.
(yelling) John! Pearl!
JOHN looks up from pebble-skimming and loosens his tie.
(yelling o.s.) Come along hee-ere and get some fuu- udge!
(calling) I don't want no fudge.
His brow is furrowed. He skims another pebble.
(shouting o.s.) You'll do what you're told!
They unwillingly get moving.
You go set down by the River.
(getting up) Oh, Icey, I'm a sight!
Get along with you.
Both women set off, WILLA to River, ICEY towards GROUP. W TRACK after ICEY. PREACHER approaches. ICEY, crossing him gives him a little shove towards WILLA and a coy --
You!!!
We FOLLOW her to the women who are busying themselves wit the fudge.
...a few men in BACKGROUND, and, beyond them, PREACHER si down by WILLA at water's edge. JOHN and PEARL approach. A ICEY starts yammering the men, WALT among them, shyly  withdraw.

That young lady'd better look sharp  or some smart sister between here  and Captina's a-gonna snap him up  right from under her nose! (they nod and agree,  ad lib) She's not the only fish in the river! (more agreement. John  and Pearl join Icey.  Icey speaks to John) Now you two stay put!
He looks hard towards WILLA and PREACHER o.s.
(o.s., to women) Shilly-shallying around...
...from JOHN'S VIEWPOINT in tableau of decorous courtship framed by heavy domestic bodies.
(o.s.) A husband's one piece of store goods  ye never know till you get it home  and take the paper off.
They sit by the water; drooling willows; almost in traves of a romantic scene. WILLA dabbles one hand in the water.
(very shy) Did Ben Harper ever tell you what he  done with that money he stole?
His head goes slantwise and he smiles oddly.
My dear child, don't you know?
He watches intently towards his mother; PEARL holds his h ICEY'S voice o.s.

She's moonin' about Ben Harper. That  wasn't love, it was just flapdoodle. (agreeing nods and  murmurs) Have some fudge, lambs. (she hands some down  to John and Pearl.  Pearl smears her  mouth with it; John,  watching always  towards his mother,  takes one nibble and  throws the rest away) When you're married forty years, you  know all that don't amount to a hill  o'beans! I been married to my Walt  that long, and I'll swear in all  that time I'd just lie there thinking  about my canning.
In BACKGROUND WALT looks sheepish.
(calling o.s.) John! John?
All look towards her.
WILLA is standing, beckoning JOHN
They start towards their mother.
A woman's a fool to marry for that.  It's something for a man. The good  Lord never meant for a decent woman  to want that -- not really want it!  It's all just a fake and a pipe-dream.

...as JOHN and PEARL (with DOLL) come shyly up. WILLA is  seated again. She is radiant.

ICEY clucks her tongue o.s.
(yelling) John: Pearl:
She appears at head of stairs. Her voice crackles with  authority.
John! Pearl! Shake a leg! (she claps her hands  sharply)
(continuing) I won't have you worryin' poor Mister  Powell another minute!
A short pause; then the children, covered with coal-dust, emerge into the light and climb the stairs. JOHN'S head i hung in defeat. As they enter the kitchen we PULL BACK.
Just look at you! Dust and filth  from top to toe!

head_text.subj: THE CHILDREN, OVER PREACHER AND ICEY

text: Want me to take 'em up and wash 'em  good?
Thank you, no. Thank you, dear Icey.  I'll tend to them. Thank you.
ICEY pats JOHN'S head.
Don't be too hard on 'em, Reverend.  Poor motherless children.
JOHN looks to PEARL and we PAN HER IN as PREACHER'S hand  named LOVE moves through her locks. We PAN with PREACHER ICEY as they move towards the door.
Remember now Mister Powell, don't be  afraid to call on us. Good night.
He watches ICEY leave, o.s.
(o.s.) Good night Miz Spoon, and thank you  again.
ICEY goes away along path outside. PREACHER, his back to watches her a moment, then turns.
Weren't you afraid, my little lambs,  down there in all that dark?
Wondering what to do next.
We begin with HEAD CLOSE-UP of BIRDIE as he rocks, and PU BACK He is rocking; and drunk. A bottle stands beside the picture. He turns and speaks to the picture.
They'll think it was me! They'll  think it was old Uncle Birdie!
His hands grip the edge of the chest on either side of th picture, which we now see.
If you'd o' seen it, Bess! I'm drunk  as a lord and I know it, but...
(o.s. continuing) Sweet Heaven, if you'd o' seen it!
BIRDIE picks up the bottle. His hand and the liquor tremb
(continuing) Down there in the deep place... her  hair wavin' lazy and soft like meadow  grass under flood waters and that  slit in her throat just like she had  an extry mouth.
(o.s.) And there ain't mortal human I can  tell but you...
(continuing) ...Bess, for if I go to the Law  they'll hang it on to me.
The bottle falls from his hand onto its side on the edge the chest.
The reverse angle of the opening shot. BIRDIE rocks heavi liquor gurgles from bottle to floor.
Sweet Heaven save poor old Uncle  Birdie!

PREACHER sits at head of table. JOHN stands to PREACHER'S right, around corner of table; he remains expressionless immobile, until he speaks. PEARL stands to JOHN'S right,  hugging the DOLL. The table is loaded with good food. PREACHER, well-fed and at leisure, dabs his mouth delicat with his napkin, folds it, puts it in a ring, and folds h hands. He waits.
(at last) I'm hungry.
Why, sure. And there's fried chicken  and candied sweets and cornsticks  and apple cobbler!
Can I have my supper please?
Naturally.
Can I have milk too?
Yes. But first of all we'll have a  little talk.
PEARL frowns and puts her finger in her mouth; she rememb he twisted her arm.
(softly) About our secrets.
No.
Why, pray tell?
Because John said I mustn't.
He slaps the table; his eyes crackle.
NEVER -- MIND -- WHAT -- JOHN --  SAID!
PEARL starts to snivel.
John is a meddler. Stop sniveling.  Looky here a minute!
He brings out the knife.
Know what this is?
PEARL shakes her head for no.
Want to see something cute? Looky  now!
He touches the spring; the blade flicks open.
How about that! This is what I use  on meddlers.
He lays the open knife on the table.
John might be a meddler.
PEARL thinks the knife is a toy and crosses behind JOHN t pick it up.
NO -- no, my lamb. Don't touch it!  Now don't touch my knife! That makes  me mad. Very, very mad.
She hugs the DOLL and he puts the hand named LOVE on her  curls.
Just tell me now; where's the money  hid?
(affectionately) But I swore. I promised John I  wouldn't tell.
JOHN -- DOESN'T -- MATTER! Can't I  get that through your head, you poor,  silly, disgusting little wretch!
Her mouth quivers; a large tear brims in her eyes.
There now! You made me lose my temper!
I'm sorry! I'm real sorry!
PEARL sniffles and wipes her eyes with her free fist.
(in a caressing tone) Now! Where's it hid, honey?
(suddenly and lightly) I'll tell.
(lightly) I thought I told you to keep your  mouth shut --
(light and quick) NO, -- it ain't fair to make Pearl  tell when she swore she wouldn't.  I'll tell.
PREACHER'S EYES CRINKLE and he turns to PEARL, smiling  brightly.
(chuckling) Well I declare! Sometimes I think  poor John will make it to heaven  yet!
His eyes snap back to JOHN and his voice is like a whip.
All right boy: where's the money?
In the cellar. Buried under a stone  in the floor.
He closes and pockets the knife. His eyes never leave JOH
It'll go hard, boy, if I find you're  lyin'.
PEARL gapes up at JOHN as he speaks.
I ain't lyin'. Go look for yourself.
...as he gets up, cellar door in BACKGROUND.
All right... (he turns towards the  door; then glances  around) Come along.
What?
Go ahead of me -- the both of you.
They cross him, towards the door.
The CHILDREN precede PREACHER, who carries a candle in ho PEARL is gaping at JOHN'S lie. JOHN is looking left and r casing the joint.
(continuing) You don't reckon I'd leave you.
(with forced lightness) Don't you believe me?
(sardonically) Why sure, boy, sure.
Now they are at bottom of stairs. JOHN sees PEARL'S expre and takes her hand.
Now where, boy? Mind; no tricks. I  can't abide liars.
Yonder.
He squeezes PEARL'S hand harder, and points.

JOHN points out a place beneath a shelf laden with Mason  jars; it is at the most distant part of the cellar from t stairs. PREACHER starts toward it, leaving them at foot of stairs then turns, catching JOHN'S ruse.
(sardonic) O no you don't!
He shepherds them ahead of him.
They arrive beneath the shelf.
Now: Where?
(lying magnificently,  meeting Preacher's  eyes) Under the stone in the floor.
PREACHER sets the candle on a barrel near the shelf-prop sinks to his knees below shot as PEARL gapes at JOHN and  JOHN looks stony. She seems about to speak.

head_text.subj: JOHN SQUEEZES PEARL'S HAND HARD CLOSE SHO

text: His hands sweep dust and expose concrete. He straightens his knees and turns to the children in close BACKGROUND.
...as he turns.
This is concrete.
A moment's silence.
John made a Sin. John told a lie.
PREACHER gets slowly to his feet and puts on his "listeni look. His sincerity is beyond doubt.
The Lord's a-talkin' to me now. He's  a-sayin', "a liar is an abomination  before mine eyes."
He takes his knife out, and springs it open.
Speak, boy: Where's it hid? (the knife pricks the  flesh under John's  ear) Speak; before I cut your throat and  leave you to drip like a hog hung up  in butcherin' time!
She starts to sob.
Pearl, shut up! Pearl, you swore!
You could save him, little bird.
(crying) Inside my doll! Inside my doll!
PREACHER is astounded. His hands fall away from JOHN. He  leans back against the wall and talks through laughter.
In the doll! Why sure! Sure!
His eyes are all over the place.
(o.s.) The last place anyone would look!

PREACHER makes a lunge across JOHN for the doll; JOHN duc under his arm, pulls PEARL forward with his left hand; he turns backwards and with his free hand, in one movement,  knocks over the candle and pulls out the support on the s
Jars shower over him; one crowns him and breaks, shedding guck, which he wipes from his eyes.
They start up the stairs.
He makes one step forward, steps on a rolling jar, and fa

They are near the top of the stairs. We hear PREACHER bel them. JOHN slips and they nearly fall backward. As JOHN  recovers, PREACHER enters the shot, his back to us. The  children get through the open door as PREACHER reaches to JOHN slams the door, catching PREACHER'S hand. PREACHER  screams. JOHN'S astonished eyes peer through the crack in the door; the door loosens; PREACHER yanks his hand loose and sucks it, groaning; the door slams to; the bolt is sh home.
...over sound of slamming bolt. He snarls like the Big Ba Wolf. All the above happens at once.
PEARL, dangling her doll, cries. JOHN panting, leans agai wall by door. JOHN is wondering what to do now. Pause.
(o.s., sweetly) Chilll-dren? (continuing) The only reason I wanted that money  is so's you could have it.
(to himself; panting) The river. That's the only where!  Uncle Birdie Steptoe!
(cooing) Puhr-urrl? Want your Mommy back? (Pearl hugs her doll) Want me to get her right now?
(sharply) John?
Hush, Pearl. Come on.
They fly out of the house.
(bellowing, as they  go) OPEN THAT DOOR, YOU SPAWN OF THE  DEVIL'S OWN STRUMPET!

A pretty, pastoral shot of the house in light mist, as th run across and leave the shot. Before they disappear, we  hear PREACHER'S fists hammering against the door. We stay the house at leisure; we hear him lunging, shoulder to do we begin to hear squeaking of hinges and splintering of w

An ultra romantic image of shelter and peace. Frogs or ri noises o.s., then the rattle of running footsteps. The  children center, their backs to us, sprinting towards the boat. Light mist as in previous shot.
(calling) Uncle Birdie! Uncle Birdie!
We shoot over BESS'S turned photograph and over BIRDIE, c passed out in his rocker. The children run through open d in BACKGROUND and JOHN runs up to BIRDIE.
Uncle Birdie!
(gesturing feebly) Don't!
Hide us Uncle Birdie! He's a-comin'  with his knife!
He grabs BIRDIE'S shoulder; BIRDIE half-rises, and falls  face down on floor.
It's me! John Harper and Pearl! You  said to come a-runnin' if we needed  you!
BIRDIE rears on one elbow and looks up at him.
(in friendly  recognition) Johnny!
He falls face down again.
JOHN grabs BIRDIE by one ear, turning his face up.
Uncle -- Birdie! Oh -- please! Please  wake up!
He looks up earnestly at JOHN.
I never done it, boy. Sweet Heaven I  never done such a terrible thing!  I'll swear on the Book to it, boy! I  never done it! I never!
He is lost; and he becomes a man.
(o.s.) Lord save poor old Uncle Birdie  Steptoe that never hurt a fly! (he snores, softly)
(quiet) There's still the river. -- The skiff  is down by the willows.
He masterfully takes PEARL by the hand and leads her into the night.

We shoot from the river. They struggle through the sumac pokeberry weeds at edge of river, towards skiff, whose pr tethered to willow, we see throughout this un-moving shot at our extreme right. When they come opposite skiff -- wh is a few yards out from shore --
PEARL, frankly bored, dangling her doll, is yawning. JOHN as he finishes undoing rope from a willow root, looks up around, checking on pursuit. His eyes fix.
On the bank above, it is huge in the mist. Same camera  position as foregoing; new angle.
BACK view: skiff in BACKGROUND. Same camera position; new angle.
(whispering) Please be quiet -- Oh please, Pearl!
(natural voice) John, where are we g --
Hush.
Same position and angle as before. PREACHER'S own figure advances to supplant his shadow. He peers downward, his open knife catching the light.
(businesslike) Children?
He starts slashing his way down through the brush-filth.
Same camera position as before. They are floundering thro mud, half-way to the skiff.
Same position and angle as in previous shot of him. He is half-way down the bank. With his knife, he hacks at an  entangling vine.
Position and angle as before. They reach the skiff. Hacki sounds o.s.
Get in the skiff, Pearl, goodness,  goodness, hurry!
(hesitant) That's Daddy!
He picks her up and throws her into the skiff.
...as they land, sprawling, in bottom of skiff among fish heads and bait cans. JOHN gets in after them.
He tears free of brush to edge of river, knife glittering
With his oar, he tries to push the boat free of mud.
He wades towards them, knee-deep in mud.
He is shoving at the oar even more desperately.
Straining.
He flounders deeper and more heavily through the mud; muc closer.
He pushes the boat free of mud.
He hurries much closer through shallow water. Prow of boa in FOREGROUND.
Wait, you little whelps! Wait!
Another step forward and he does a pratt-fall and makes a splash.
He is trying to feather the boat out to where the current will catch it. In panic and haste he is clumsy.
Why can't I do it when I know how to  do it!
...as he gets up, at edge of mud.
Wait! Wait! I'll slit your guts!

The current catches it and spins it round like a leaf. JO efforts with the oars are useless. PREACHER enters, wadin fast. His hands are within an inch of reaching the helple skiff; capriciously the current takes it downstream.
The skiff is taken steadily by the current. PEARL sits up doll in arms. JOHN is almost asleep with exhaustion.
It is well away from him and getting smaller. Waist-deep, wades a couple of steps after it, then just looks.
He begins a steady, rhythmical, animal scream of outrage loss.

head_text.subj: THE RIVER AND LANDSCAPE, FEATURING STARLIGHT

text: JOHN is asleep. PEARL sits sleepily whispering to her dol
Once upon a time there was a pretty  fly, and he had a wife, this pretty  fly...
(o.s.) ...and one day she flew away, and  then one night his two pretty fly  children...

head_text.subj: THE MOVING SKIFF, THROUGH DEW-JEWELED SPI

text: (o.s., continuing) ...flew away too, into the sky, into  the moon...
A big frog is profiled; the skiff drifts by in distance; frog twangs out a bass-note.
As the card is turned to the handwritten side we

(reading aloud) Dear Walt and Icey: I bet you been  worried and gave us up for lost.  Took the kids down here with me for  a visit to my sister Elsie's farm.  Thot a little change of scenery would  do us all a world of good after so  much trubble and heartache. At least  the kids will git a plenty of good  home cooking. Your devoted Harry  Powell
Now ain't you relieved, Walt?
Sure, but you was worried too, Mother;  takin' off with never a word of  goodbye. I even got to figurin' them  gypsies busted in and done off with  all three of 'em.
You and your gypsies! They been gone  a week!
Not before one of 'em knifed a farmer  and stole his horse. Never caught  the gypsies nor the horse.
A man is going along a river lane on horseback. It is PREACHER; he walks the horse away from us.
We descend to a poor riverside farmhouse; JOHN and PEARL  tether a boat in front of it.
They are eating hot boiled potatoes. A glance at JOHN and PEARL, and they turn away towards lane in BACKGROUND. JOH and PEARL proceed towards the house.
We shoot from within open door of kitchen. JOHN and PEARL advance to edge of porch. A TIRED FARM WOMAN stands by do within. We shoot OVER her.
Hungry, I s'pose. Well, I'll see if  there's any more potatoes to spare.  Where's your folks?
Ain't got none.
Woman leaves shot briefly (we HOLD on CHILDREN) She re-en and goes to them with a bowl of steaming potatoes. They t hands-ful, and make to eat.
Go 'way; go 'way.
They turn away and walk towards boat. She looks after the
Such times, when youngins run the  roads!
She leaves the SHOT. We frame them briefly, walking away, then;
It is lit by firelight. It reads: PEACH-PICKERS WANTED WEEKLY HIRE
(o.s.) An ungrateful child is an  abomination...
PREACHER stands behind the flames; in FOREGROUND an OLD M sits profiled on a box. Other workers, all men, sit aroun fire.
(continuing) ...before the eyes of God. The world  is fast going to damnation because  of impudent youngins a-flyin' in the  face of Age.
Short silence, as the other men look at PREACHER without  liking. Then the old man spits into the fire.
A spurt of steam as spit strikes.
...hooting.
He comes down to water.
(o.s.) They make soup out of them...
Full landscape in BACKGROUND.
(continuing) ...but I wouldn't know how to go  about gettin' him open.

head_text.subj: CHILDREN AND SKIFF, OVER RABBITS IN GRASS

text: We shoot OVER two sitting rabbits as they watch, their ea up. The skiff passes. PEARL plays with doll JOHN unsnarls line.

head_text.subj: THE CHILDREN AND SKIFF, FRAMED BY WILLOWS --

text: The skiff passes. Baa-ing of sheep o.s.
The sheep bleats. We PAN in a big barn near the river, th a lighted house; willows along shore.
JOHN re-sets his oar. They angle towards us for the shore
We're gonna spend a night on land.
...they reach top of the bank. Corner of barn and lighted window in BACKGROUND. Sounds of mouth-organ and girl sing o.s.

head_text.subj: A LIGHTED WINDOW, THE SHADE DRAWN

text: A wire bird-cage hangs close to the shade, silhouetted. O the perch, a canary. Lullaby and mouth-organ continue o. After a moment the CHILDREN enter, backs to us, and stop, looking.
Window-light on faces, song over. A moment.
Are we goin' home, John?
Ssh...
He turns, her hand in his. We PAN as they tiptoe towards big, open door of barn; big open hayloft window above.
As they walk down aisle of barn we shoot them past bellie and legs of row of cows. Sounds of munching and soft lowi o.s. JOHN helps PEARL up a little ladder to the hayloft.
...as the CHILDREN bed down in hay, only legs visible,  protruding into frame of window, which frames a middle-di white lane beyond house, and a landscape. Whippoorwill o. A DARKENING OF LIGHT.
The full moon is half-risen. Whippoorwill o.s.
The moon is well above the horizon. Whippoorwill o.s.
The moon is still higher. A pause; the whippoorwill stops mid-phrase. Brief pause; then John sits up into silhouett
He listens intently. We hear nothing. His eyes alter. We  hear, distantly
(o.s., singing) Leaning, Leaning...
At various distances o.s., we hear dogs barking at the so of the singing.
(continuing; louder) ...safe and secure from all alarms;
The dog from the farm rushes braying to his gate. Other d continue o.s. PREACHER appears, astride his walking horse singing.
Leaning...
Watching; dread and despair. Sounds go.
(o.s.) Leaning; Leaning on the Everlasting  Arms.
He approaches and crosses center screen, continuing the h (We do not PAN with him; he crosses the frame of the grea window.)
Eyes following PREACHER. PREACHER and dogs continue o.s.
(to himself) Don't you never sleep?
He vanishes beyond trees, his singing more distant. Dogs  continue.
He wakes her. PREACHER'S singing o.s.
(scared whisper) Pearl, wake up! Come on, Pearl!
He vanishes; scuttling of children in hay, o.s.; dogs qui his song dies. Brief silence. The whippoorwill resumes.
Hand in hand, they hurry out of barn and, as we PAN, alon its side, towards River, o.s. Whippoorwill o.s.
The whippoorwill's singing continues o.s.
JOHN steers through turbulent, moonlit water. Whippoorwil continues. Low moon.
Blank, calm water; the skiff enters and passes full lengt below us, the CHILDREN asleep in it; blank water again; a the fox barks.

head_text.subj: THE SKIFF, DRIFTING SHOT THROUGH RIVERSIDE

text: Crickets o.s. The skiff nears a sand-bar.
The prow softly grates against sand.

head_text.subj: THE GROUNDED SKIFF, AGAIN THROUGH GRASS

text: Crickets fainter. TILTING UPWARD.
Distant; medium; the near; roosters crow o.s.
He looks to PEARL o.s.

PEARL is picking daisies. A fence up beyond her. Beyond t fence, a woman, RACHEL COOPER, appears. She carries a ber basket on her arm. JOHN scrambles up, grabs an oar, and h it defensively. PEARL freezes.
(loud) You two youngsters get up here to me  this instant!
(o.s.) Mind me now!
JOHN lowers the oar at the female authority in her voice.
(o.s.) Now git on up to my house.
They hesitate.
I'll git me a willow switch.
They still hesitate. She breaks off a switch and comes fo them, squishing through the mud. She surrounds them and d them like geese up the bank.
They move across the meadow like a nursery frieze. She tw with her switch. As she goes near PEARL'S calves, JOHN tu
Don't you hurt her!
Hurt her nothin'! Wash her's more  like it! (hand to mouth, yelling) Ruby!
Three crouching figures pick tomatoes beyond a low white  fence; Rachel's house in background. RUBY, thirteen, pops her head up like a rifle-target.
(o.s.) Clary!
Clary, eleven, pops up.
(o.s.) Mary!
Mary, four, pops up.
(in chorus) Yes Miz Cooper!

head_text.subj: RACHEL AND HARPERS, MOVING TOWARDS FENCE

text: She has JOHN and PEARL by their napes.
Bring yer baskets.
The three girls enter, their backs to us, carrying basket of tomatoes.

head_text.subj: THE GIRLS, OVER RACHEL AND HARPER CHILDREN

text: She holds JOHN and PEARL very firmly, inspecting baskets, across gate of fence.

Nicely picked, Clary. Mary; put the  big ones on top. Ruby, most o' them  ain't fit to go to market. Put them  baskets down. Ruby, fetch the washtub  and put it by the pump. Mary, Clary,  fetch me a bar o' laundry soap and  the scrub brush.
(in chorus) Yes Miz Cooper!
They hurry off.
Come on, now; up to the house.
She opens the gate, pushes the Harper children through, s the gate, and walks between them, her back to us. The chi hesitate. She turns to them and stops.
She looks them up and down. If we saw her face, her lips  would be pursed and working with anger.
Gracious! If you hain't a sight to  beat all! Where you from?
No answer; their eyes are wide with curiosity.
Where's your folks?
(o.s.) Speak up now!
His eyes go down to her feet. He, and we, start to examin her from foot to head; for this is our heroine at last.

...from JOHN'S eye-level. We TILT SLOWLY UP her height. S wears man's shoes, heavy with mud; a rough skirt; a shape sweater hangs over her shoulders; she is in her middle si and wears a man's old hat. Her face says:
(sort of roughly) Gracious! So I've got two more mouths  to feed!
For no reason at all he feels he has come home.

head_text.subj: JOHN, PEARL, RACHEL, RUBY, DURING WASHING

text: RACHEL mercilessly scrubs JOHN; JOHN doesn't like it; RUB washes PEARL with a cloth.
Hating the scrubbing. He breaks away.
JOHN dodges behind a bush, RACHEL in hot pursuit.
RACHEL'S head bobs up and down above the bush; we hear th unmistakable sound of a female hand on a child's bottom.

head_text.subj: A SHELF, FULL OF MARKET BASKETS, NEATLY COVE

text: All carry baskets. RACHEL charges along at the head of th procession. A CATTLE DEALER strolls the other way.
Howdy Miz Cooper -- you goin' to  sell me yer hog this year?
RACHEL doesn't stop walking.
With the price o' pork what it is?
She keeps walking.
(talking to herself) I'm butcherin' my hog myself, smokin'  the hams, and cannin' the sausage. (she calls to children  over her shoulder) You-all have your work cut out!
She talks to herself.
All the time.
Your Maw's funny.
She ain't our Maw. We just live at  her house.
They walk in silence.
Where's your folks?
Some place.
My Daddy's in Dee-troit.
(to Ruby) Who's your folks?
I dunno.
A WAITRESS, wearing an apron labeled EMPIRE EATS, hurries across the street towards the GROUP. We PAN her in to MAR The procession halts briefly. She embraces MARY.
Mary! Honey! Mornin' Miz Cooper. (to Mary) Guess what! I'm savin' up to buy ye  a charm bracelet!
Never mind the gewgaws; don't you  miss your visit this Sunday; and  come to Church with us.
The WAITRESS hurries away. She dodges past a car.
See ye Sunday, love!
she follows WAITRESS, then LOVERS in car, with her eyes.
The car CENTERS, held up in traffic; two lovers in it, si close.
She takes in the LOVERS.
Women is durn fools! All of 'em!
She sighs, angry at all women, herself included, and turn away. We are at the door of a GROCERY STORE. The GROCER i on his doorstep.
(to children) Take yer baskets in.
The CHILDREN file in past her and GROCER.
(to Grocer) Looky there. (she indicates the  lovers) She'll be losin' her mind to a tricky  mouth and a full moon, and like as  not I'll be saddled with the  consequences.
She starts into store with the GROCER.
RACHEL and GROCER come up to counter.
(continuing; she takes  a list from her bosom  and gives it to Grocer) Here's what you owe me. (she counts baskets) One, two, three, four, five... where's  the other basket? Where's Ruby?
She went.

John: you go fetch Ruby. (John goes. As Grocer  empties baskets and  tots up, Rachel  continues:) Big Ruby's my problem girl. She can't  gather eggs without bustin' 'em; but  Ruby's got mother hands with a  youngin, so what're you to say?
She stands with her market-basket, reacting to wolf whist o.s.; she is seeking the world.
How 'bout tonight, Ruby?
RUBY gestures RACHEL'S nearness.
(to 1st) What gives?
The Old Lady's around. (to Ruby) How 'bout Thursday?
RUBY nods.
(to 2nd) The old gal thinks she comes in fer  sewin' lessons o'-Thursday.
(calling) Miz Cooper wants you.
He turns and goes; RUBY, with an eye to 1ST LOAFER, turns and follows.
(to Pearl) And will you show me your dolly,  little lady?
JOHN has entered in BACKGROUND. PEARL holds the doll to h and JOHN moves in quietly to her side. They stand togethe as so often before.
See ye got two more peeps to your  brood.
Yeah, and ornerier than the rest.
How's your own boy, Miz Cooper?

Ain't heard from Ralph since last  Christmas. Don't matter -- I've got  a new crop. (she laughs. Loudly) I'm a strong tree with branches for  many birds. I'm good for something  in this old world and I know it,  too! We know that she will rout the  Devil.
(a good tradesman) Got a good buy in soap, Miz Cooper.
(triumphant) Don't need no soap. I'm boilin' down  the fat from my hog.
CENTERING RACHEL as she takes a book from table, and the  GIRLS MOVE to set at her seat, and JOHN stands to one sid RACHEL glances at him.
He looks suspiciously to the Book in her hands, for to hi it has come to mean only Preacher.
...as she opens it on her lap o.s. we hear a screen door  open.

We see the door closing as JOHN goes out. The girls sit o low stools in semi-circle at RACHEL'S feet. We CENTER RAC RACHEL, keenly aware of JOHN, pretends to ignore him. JOH crosses behind her and stands with his back to us. We see the back of his head through the screen. RACHEL, changing her mind about what story to tell, finds the new page she after, and spreads her hands flat on the pages. She never glances at the text. She is fishing for JOHN.

Now old Pharoah, he was the King of  Egyptland! And he had a daughter,  and once upon a time (louder) she was walkin' along the river bank  and she seen somethin' bumpin' and  scrapin' along down on a sandbar  under the willows.

head_text.subj: THE BACK OF JOHN'S HEAD, IMMOBILE

text: (o.s.) And do you know what it was, children?
(excited) No!
No!
(still loud) Well, now, it was a skiff, washed up  on the bar. And who do you reckon  was in it?
